Extracts that exhibited >80% growth inhibition at 10 μg/ml, or >50% growth inhibition at 2 μg/ml against at least one of the tested parasites was considered active. Of the 235 extracts in our library, 125 (53%) fulfilled these activity criteria. A total of 34 (27%) of the active extracts exhibited activity against T. b. rhodesiense, L. donovani, and P. falciparum collectively. Regarding parasite species-selective inhibition, P. falciparum appeared to be the most susceptible parasite, followed by T. b. rhodesiense and L. donovani. Among the tested parasites T. cruzi was the least susceptible towards the plant extracts (
Figure 1 ).
